HENRICI-OLIVE and S. OLIVE Monsanto Textiles Company, Pensacola, FL 32575 (fJS_A.) (Received May 13, 1982) The industrial low pressure (20 - 100 atm) methanol synthesis uses catalysts based on the compositions Cu/ZnO/Cr203 or Cu/ZnO/A1203. Whereas Cr203 or A1203 is considered non-essential, the presence of both copper and zinc oxide is vital for satisfactory catalysis, the combination of both being several orders of magnitude more effective than either of the two components [1] . This mutual promotion has intrigued several authors (e.g. [1 - 3] ), but no satisfactory- mechanism has been found as vet. Based on 3 broad spectrum of detailed experimental results found in the literature, we would like to suggest a mechanism for this amazing case of synergism. The most useful pieces of information come from the comprehensive study by Herman et aG [1] concerning catalysts of various compositions. While after calcination the mixed catalysts consist of hexagonal ZnO and tetragonal CuO, the actual active catalyst, after reduction or after use, is made up essentially of metallic Cu and ZnO. However, there is spectra:. evidence for the presence of Cu(1) species which are visualized as `dissolved' in ZnO. From the known facts that Cut ions form carbonyls [4, 5] and that. ZnO activates molecular hydrogen by heterolytic splitting, giving rise tc -ZnH and -OH groups [6] , Herman et: aL concluded that CO is cootdinatively bonded to a Cu(1) center, and that H., is heterolytically split by a nearby ZnO center, the proton attacking the carbon end and t-he hydride ion attacking the oxygen end of the CO molecule. (Since the dipole of CO has its negative side at the O and not at C, the contrary would have appeared more probable.) Herman et aL. also assumed that the synthesis proceeds as a surface reaction, because no special pore distribution was found necessary for highly effective catalysis. However, it should 6e taken into consideration that Cu(1) itself is well able to decompose hydrogen [7] , and also to form hydrides [3, 8] . We therefore suggest that at least one of the major effects of the ZnO component is to stabilize the catalytically active Cu(1) state, for instance in the form of `end groups' of ZnO chains which may formally be written as: Cu(1)-0-Zn(11)--3-Zn(1I). .: 0304-5102/82/0000-0000/$02.75 Esevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 90 (Actually the structure is, of course, three-dimensional.) At the surface such Cu(I) species could easily coordinate to one or several CO molecules, under the reaction conditions of the methanol synthesis.
